{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
â
[[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example of that is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolizing]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref>
+
[[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example of that is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolizing]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> </ref> Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor claim that the Mubarak family is worth from $40 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mubarak-billion-2011-2|author=Gus Lubin|title=If Forced To Leave, Mubarak Could Take Estimated Fortune Of $40-$70 Billion|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=05 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=[[ABC NEWS]]|accessdate=05 February 2011}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
